| Title | URL | Chunk |
|-------|-----|-------|
| Web Search Results |  | Transitioning your add-on to the Blender Extensions Platform is a strategic move that enhances accessibility and streamlines the update process for users. The Blender Extensions Platform serves as an online directory for free and open-source extensions, allowing users to discover, install, and manage add-ons directly within Blender. ([extensions.blender.org](https://extensions.blender.org/about/?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>With the introduction of this platform, the need for third-party update mechanisms, such as the CGCookie Updater, is effectively eliminated. The CGCookie Updater was designed to enable users to check for add-on updates and install new versions directly from within Blender. ([github.com](https://github.com/CGCookie/blender-addon-updater?utm_source=openai)) However, the Extensions Platform now provides a native solution for these functionalities, ensuring a more integrated and user-friendly experience.<br/><br/>To adapt your add-on for the Extensions Platform, you'll need to create a repository that complies with the platform's specifications. This involves preparing your add-on with the necessary metadata and ensuring it adheres to the guidelines outlined in the Blender Manual. ([docs.blender.org](https://docs.blender.org/manual/en/latest/advanced/extensions/index.html?utm_source=openai)) Once your add-on is published on the platform, users can easily install and update it directly through Blender's interface, simplifying the distribution and maintenance process.<br/><br/>By removing the CGCookie Updater and leveraging the Blender Extensions Platform, you align your add-on with Blender's evolving ecosystem, offering users a seamless and efficient method to access and manage your extension. |

</details>
</tool-use>

The Extensions Platform inherently manages these processes, ensuring users have access to the latest versions without additional tools. ([code.blender.org](https://code.blender.org/2024/05/extensions-platform-beta-release/?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>To adapt your add-on for the Extensions Platform, you'll need to create a repository that complies with the platform's specifications. This involves preparing your add-on with the necessary metadata and ensuring it adheres to the guidelines outlined in the Blender Manual. ([docs.blender.org](https://docs.blender.org/manual/en/latest/advanced/extensions/index.html?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>By aligning your add-on with the Extensions Platform, you enhance its accessibility and maintainability, providing a more seamless experience for Blender users. |

| Web Search Results |  | Transitioning your add-on to the Blender Extensions platform is a strategic move that simplifies distribution and management for users. The Blender Extensions platform serves as an online directory for free and open-source extensions, allowing users to find, install, and update add-ons directly within Blender. ([extensions.blender.org](https://extensions.blender.org/about/?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>Given that the Extensions platform provides built-in mechanisms for managing add-ons, including installation and updates, the CGCookie updater becomes redundant in this context. Therefore, it's advisable to remove the CGCookie updater from your add-on when integrating it with the Extensions platform.<br/><br/>To begin the transition, ensure your add-on complies with the platform's guidelines and licensing requirements. The official Blender Extensions platform only offers GNU GPL-compliant software. ([extensions.blender.org](https://extensions.blender.org/about/?utm_source=openai)) Detailed instructions on creating and publishing extensions are available in the Blender Manual. ([docs.blender.org](https://docs.blender.org/manual/en/latest/advanced/extensions/index.html?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>By aligning your add-on with the Blender Extensions platform, you enhance its accessibility and maintainability, providing a more seamless experience for users. |

</details>
</tool-use>

<tool-use data-tool-type="search" data-tool-name="web_search">
<details>
            <summary>Tool use: **web_search** • Searched web `extensions.blender.org addon submission requirements format` • **1** results</summary>
        
| Title | URL | Chunk |
|-------|-----|-------|
| Web Search Results |  | To transition your add-on to the Blender Extensions Platform and remove the CGCookie updater, follow these steps:<br/><br/>1. **Prepare Your Add-on for the Extensions Platform:**<br/>   - Ensure your add-on complies with the GNU General Public License (GPL), as the platform only accepts GPL-compliant software.<br/>   - Create a `.zip` file containing your add-on and a manifest file with metadata, replacing the need for `bl_info`. ([docs.blender.org](https://docs.blender.org/manual/en/latest/advanced/extensions/index.html?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>2. **Remove the CGCookie Updater:**<br/>   - The CGCookie updater is designed for manual update checks and installations within Blender. ([github.com](https://github.com/CGCookie/blender-addon-updater?utm_source=openai))<br/>   - Since the Extensions Platform handles updates automatically, you can remove the CGCookie updater from your add-on's codebase.<br/><br/>3. **Upload Your Add-on to the Extensions Platform:**<br/>   - Visit [extensions.blender.org](https://extensions.blender.org/) and sign in with your Blender ID.<br/>   - Follow the guidelines in the [User Manual](https://docs.blender.org/manual/en/latest/advanced/extensions/index.html) to upload your add-on.<br/>   - After submission, your add-on will undergo a review process before becoming available to users.<br/><br/>By completing these steps, your add-on will be integrated into the Blender Extensions Platform, allowing users to install and update it directly within Blender without the need for the CGCookie updater. |

</details>
</tool-use>

  &quot;plan&quot;: &quot;# Convert to Blender Extension Platform\n\n## Overview\nRemove the CGCookie updater system and prepare the addon for the Blender Extension Platform, which handles updates natively.\n\n## Changes Required\n\n### 1. Remove Updater Module\n- Delete the &#96;updater/&#96; directory and all its contents\n- Remove &#96;from . import updater&#96; import from &#96;__init__.py&#96;\n- Remove &#96;updater.register()&#96; and &#96;updater.unregister()&#96; calls\n- Remove &#96;updater.check_for_updates()&#96; call on startup\n- Remove the &#96;check_for_updates_handler&#96; from &#96;bpy.app.handlers.load_post&#96; (in updater module)\n\n### 2. Update &#96;__init__.py&#96;\n- Remove update-related properties from &#96;BST_AddonPreferences&#96;:\n  - &#96;check_for_updates&#96; (BoolProperty)\n  - &#96;update_check_interval&#96; (IntProperty)\n- Remove update-related UI from &#96;BST_AddonPreferences.draw()&#96;:\n  - Remove the \&quot;Update Settings\&quot; box and all its contents\n  - Remove references to &#96;updater.UpdaterState&#96;\n  - Remove operators &#96;bst.check_for_updates&#96; and &#96;bst.install_update&#96;\n- Keep AutoMat Extractor preferences as requested\n\n### 3. Update &#96;bl_info.json&#96;\n- Ensure version format matches between &#96;__init__.py&#96; and &#96;bl_info.json&#96; (currently &#96;(0, 9, 1)&#96; vs &#96;[0, 10, 0]&#96;)\n- Verify all required fields are present for Extension Platform compatibility\n\n### 4. Update Dependencies\n- Review &#96;requirements.txt&#96; - if &#96;requests&#96; is only used by the updater, consider removing it\n- Check if any other modules use &#96;requests&#96; before removing from requirements\n\n### 5. Clean Up References\n- Search codebase for any remaining references to updater functionality\n- Remove any update-related documentation from &#96;readme.md&#96;\n\n## Files to Modify\n- &#96;__init__.py&#96; - Remove updater imports, registration, and preferences\n- &#96;bl_info.json&#96; - Verify format and version consistency\n- &#96;readme.md&#96; - Remove update-related documentation\n- &#96;requirements.txt&#96; - Review and potentially remove &#96;requests&#96; dependency\n\n## Files to Delete\n- &#96;updater/__init__.py&#96;\n- &#96;updater/&#96; directory (entire folder)\n&quot;,

Download the addon (zip file)\r\n2. In Blender, go to Edit &gt; Preferences &gt; Add-ons\r\n3. Click \&quot;Install...\&quot; and select the downloaded zip file, or click and drag if it allows.\r\n4. Ensure addon is enabled.\r\n\r\n## Usage\r\n\r\n1. Open blender file/scene to optimize\r\n2. Open side panel &gt; Edit tab &gt; Bulk Scene Tools\r\n3. Data remapper: Select data types to remap. Currently supports Images, Materials, and Fonts. Select to exclude data type from remapping.\r\n4. View amount of duplicates and use the dropdown menus to select which duplicate groups to exclude from remapping.\r\n5. Remap. This action is undo-able!\r\n6. If remapping has successfully remapped to your liking, Purge Unused Data so that the Viewport Display function has less materials to calculate, unless you are applying it only to selected objects.\r\n7. Recommend activating Solid viewport shading mode so you can see what the Material Viewport function is doing. Change color from Material to Texture if you prefer; the function should find the diffuse texture if one exists.\r\n8. Apply material calculation to selected objects if preferred.\r\n9. Manually set display color for objects that couldn&#39;t be calculated, or weren&#39;t calculated to your preference.\r\n\r\n## Workflow for unpacking and organizing all textures\r\n\r\n1. Pack all images (File &gt; external data &gt; pack resources, or BST &gt; Bulk Path Management &gt; Workflow &gt; Pack)\r\n2. Rename all image (datablocks) as preferred (can be easily done within the Bulk Operations dropdown, but I also recommend the Simple Renaming extension available from the Blender community)\r\n3. Remap all image paths as preferred (Bulk Operations)\r\n4. Bulk Path Management &gt; Save All (If selected, will save selected, if none are selected, will save all images in file)\r\n5. Remove pack\r\n\r\n## Author\r\n\r\n- **RaincloudTheDragon**&quot;

## Update Overview
- `__init__.py` now just exposes the AutoMat preference UI and registers core panels/ops without any updater hooks; metadata matches the extension release version `(0, 10, 0)` so Blender and the manifest stay in sync. ```1:105:__init__.py
bl_info = {
    "name": "Raincloud's Bulk Scene Tools",
    ...
    "version": (0, 10, 0),
    "blender": (4, 5, 0),
}
...
        box = layout.box()
        box.label(text="AutoMat Extractor Settings")
        row = box.row()
        row.prop(self, "automat_common_outside_blend")
```
- Added `blender_manifest.toml` with the schema/version/id/permissions that the Blender Extension Platform expects, modeled after the BasedPlayblast example for consistent fields and build exclusions ([BasedPlayblast manifest](https://github.com/RaincloudTheDragon/BasedPlayblast/blob/main/blender_manifest.toml)). ```1:28:blender_manifest.toml
schema_version = "1.0.0"

id = "raincloud.bulk_scene_tools"
name = "Raincloud's Bulk Scene Tools"
...
[permissions]
files = "Read and write external resources referenced by scenes"
```
- Removed the legacy updater implementation (`updater/` and `bl_info.json`), dropped the obsolete “Automatic update checking” docs, and cleared the unused `requests` dependency so the extension bundle is self-contained. ```1:33:readme.md
## Features

- Bulk Data Remap
- Bulk Viewport Display
```

## Testing
- Not run (not requested).

Register classes from this module (do this first to ensure preferences are available)\r\n    for cls in classes:\r\n        bpy.utils.register_class(cls)\r\n    \r\n    # Print debug info about preferences\r\n    try:\r\n        prefs = bpy.context.preferences.addons.get(__package__)\r\n        if prefs:\r\n            print(f\&quot;Addon preferences registered successfully: {prefs}\&quot;)\r\n        else:\r\n            print(\&quot;WARNING: Addon preferences not found after registration!\&quot;)\r\n            print(f\&quot;Available addons: {&#39;, &#39;.join(bpy.context.preferences.addons.keys())}\&quot;)\r\n    except Exception as e:\r\n        print(f\&quot;Error accessing preferences: {str(e)}\&quot;)\r\n    \r\n    # Unregister classes from this module\r\n    for cls in reversed(classes):\r\n        try:\r\n            bpy.utils.unregister_class(cls)\r\n        except RuntimeError:\r\n            pass\r\n\r\nif __name__ == \&quot;__main__\&quot;:\r\n    register()\r\n&quot;
}

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Summarizing extension ID fix**</details></think>

---

Blender flagged the extension because `blender_manifest.toml` used `id = "raincloud.bulk_scene_tools"`, and IDs must be valid Python identifiers (letters, digits, underscores only). I switched the manifest ID to `raincloud_bulk_scene_tools`, matching the Blender Extensions schema illustrated in the BasedPlayblast example ([manifest reference](https://github.com/RaincloudTheDragon/BasedPlayblast/blob/main/blender_manifest.toml)) and bumped both the manifest version and `bl_info` tuple to `0.10.1` so they stay in sync. Re-enable the add-on and the incompatible-ID error reported at `bl_ext.vscode_development.Rainys-Bulk-Scene-Tools` (lines 81‑89 in your Blender console) should be resolved. No automated tests were run.

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Explaining module name warning and fix**</details></think>

---

Blender’s console is warning because the extension loader rejects modules whose folder names are not valid Python identifiers. Your VS Code dev scraper maps the add-on into `...extensions\vscode_development\Rainys-Bulk-Scene-Tools`, which still contains dashes, so Blender skips the module even though the manifest’s `id` is now valid. Rename the deployed folder (and the repo root when packaging) to something like `Rainys_Bulk_Scene_Tools` so the path matches Blender’s identifier rules; the manifest can keep the same id string.

The rest of the log (lines 331‑454) just shows Blender unregistering/re‑registering classes during hot reload plus unrelated BlenderKit noise, so once the folder name is updated those extension warnings will disappear and the add-on should load normally.
